body: LGTM. I'll merge.

@mboehm7 Good idea, and that will work great as part of `MLContext`.

@deroneriksson We should add this as a nice convenience method to `MLContext`.

I had an offline discussion with @lresende and @deroneriksson.
There were some concerns about the way the pom file is being done.
I'll let them carry the discussion forward.
I would strongly recommend to hold off these major features until we actually made the 0.10 release; let's focus on robustness and fixes for now. Thanks.

My primary concern is the addition of actual jars to the project and the use of system scope. The maven 'way' is typically to reference artifacts in a maven repository (not necessarily central). Would it be possible to build these jcuda artifacts and put them in a publicly accessibly maven repo and reference this repo in the pom?

Yes, since jcuda is open source, we can certainly create jcuda artifacts. Also, ideally I would prefer that too. However the problem is maintaining a public maven repo and hence I would defer that to Alan and/or Luciano.
We could add the jars on Maven central, or check if @akchinSTC can be of any help here. While first is preferable, latest might be easiest as we actually don't own jcuda.

Just to clarify, whether we go to mvn central or host repo at STC, there are two options:
1. Deploy both the jar and libs. See https://github.com/MysterionRise/mavenized-jcuda/
2. Deploy just the jar (i.e. the ones that are included). In this case, we expect users to install the libs (example: libJCublas-linux-x86_64.so or JCublas-windows-x86_64.dll).
Just FYI, I'll be out of town for a few days, so I'll get back to this next week.

@dusenberrymw No worries :)

@dusenberrymw @prithvirajsen We need to ensure that both Deep Learning DML Library and Caffe DML generator generate same DML. Of course, that would involve lot of discussion and don't know what is the recommended forum to have that discussion (mailing list, jira or PR). 

Here is an example:
Comparing forward functions in scripts/staging/SystemML-NN/nn/layers/conv_builtin.dml and src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/dl/layer/ConvolutionLayer.java: Both have same expression for forward for convolution but differ in bias. 
Caffe generator will output:

``` python
ones_2 = matrix(1.0, rows=1, cols=(P_2*Q_2));
H_2 = H_2 + matrix(bias_2 %*% ones_2, rows=1, cols=(32*(P_2*Q_2)));
```

whereas DML library will use:

``` python
for (i in 1:P_2*Q_2-1)
    bias = cbind(bias, b)  # creating shape (32, P_2*Q_2)
H_2 = H_2 + matrix(bias, rows=1, cols=32*P_2*Q_2)
```

Links:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/160/files#diff-512c25ade02fd0dd41ee07a7b415f85bR70
https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/158/files#diff-3fc6d70003f29a7bb91bac7dd043af30R113

Either ways, I think we are heading in right direction wrt DML library and Caffe DML generator. I can imagine both serving the needs/painpoints of different types of end-users :)

All tests passed [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/392/).

OK I will  exclude them except from the src.tar.gz and src.zip. Thank you.

Looks like we are changing to explicitly choose the scripts to put on the packages, to now put all except for the ones on specific folders. I am ok with that, but what to double check if all the scripts are ready to be first class scripts on the release package, otherwise we could move them to other folders as I do like your solution better.

@mboehm7 @niketanpansare  thoughts on the comment above ?

@lresende Thanks for checking on this. The 'first-class' algorithms go in the primary scripts/algorithms directory. The 'second-class' scripts go in scripts/staging, which is excluded from all the artifacts (except in the src artifacts). By including scripts/algorithms/\* and excluding scripts/staging/*, all first-class scripts are automatically included, and all second-class scripts are excluded. When an algorithm script has graduated, it is moved from scripts/staging/ to scripts/algorithms/ and will automatically be placed in each build artifact. A benefit of this PR is that we no longer need to manually add each first-class script to the assemblies, which can be error-prone.

@mboehm7 @niketanpansare Let me know if this is correct or if anything needs to be modified.

Hi,
we addressed your comments and updated the PR. In addition there are some changes one has to consider in order to run SysML with Flink:
- set HADOOP_HOME environment variable
- set `akka.framesize` to a higher value (otherwise the submitted jobs exceed this limit) e.g. 300000000b in `flink-conf.yaml`
- to submit a job to flink:
  - add yarn dependencies with `hadoop-mapreduce-client-jobclient-2.7.1.jar`
  - explicitly set the main class with `-c org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript`

We try to fix the problem with the `framesize`, so that we can set it directly in the job and will let you know when this is fixed in Flink.

Looking forward to your comments.

Thank you @nishi-t. I tested and this works on OS X. @gweidner could you try this on Windows?

I gave it a try w/ LinregDS and LinregCG, on a 1+6 node cluster and the 80GB scenario (10M x 1k, dense w/ binary inputs) and it worked fine. Awesome work - thanks @akunft @fschueler @FelixNeutatz @carabolic . Couple of comments:

1) Setup: Even with HADOOP_HOME properly configured there were issues so I disabled the respective code in InfrastructureAnalyzer. This is something, we should probably do anyway. Thanks for pointing this out. Furthermore, I had to reconfigure akka.framesize to 512MB to make these scenarios work.

2) Performance: My biggest concern right now is performance but I'm sure there are simple fixes to that or I simply misconfigured Flink. Let us have a look at the comparison to the MR and Spark backends, where I exclude the time for Spark context creation because Flink runs against an initialized cluster too:
- MR: LinregDS: 147s (2 jobs); LinregCG w/ 6 iterations: 361s (8 jobs) w/ mmchain; 628s (14 jobs) w/o mmchain
- Spark: LinregDS: 71s (3 jobs); LinregCG w/ 6 iterations: 41s (8 jobs) w/ mmchain; 48s (14 jobs) w/o mmchain
- Flink: LinregDS: 212s (3 jobs); LinregCG w/ 6 iterations: 1,047s (14 jobs) w/o mmchain

3) MMchain instruction: Maybe you could add the mmchain instruction for the special case of t(X)%_%(X%_%v) to allow a better understanding what is going on here. This would remove any potential performance influence of broadcasts as the intermediate vector of 80MB does not need to be collected and redistributed via broadcast and it also reduces the number of scans per iteration from 2 to 1. You already have the necessary function implemented. 

4) JDK7 Compatibility: It would be great to ensure backwards compatibility with JDK7, i.e., replace JDK8 methods with their JDK7 counterparts as we try to simultaneously support older deployments and dev environments.

5) FlinkExecutionContext Execute: You already commented wrt a clean handling of this call to pending dataset operations. Couldn't we remove this and simply call execute on write instructions - all other jobs are triggered when the buffer pool collects matrices from producing operations. Right?

@lresende @mboehm7 @deroneriksson @nakul02 I have removed the jars as well as system scope from our pom.xml. Also, I have updated the documentation to provide installation steps for JCuda. Please see https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/1a52bd8908773593fb8b240b38ed0e81a33ebb3f/docs/devdocs/gpu-backend.md#setup-instructions-for-jcudacontext

Tested on Windows. Absolute paths such as "C:\\example.dml" work.

I had success with "C:\\..." but not absolute paths starting with "\\" or "/" (on Windows). We might want to look into updating this in the future.
Just for reference, this pertains to [SYSTEMML-626](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-626). The header says SYSTEMML-629.

thanks @asurve - most of the following comments are due to the recent modifications of the frame integration:

1) Input/output infos: Could we consistently use binaryblock throughout the compiler, tests, and runtime for both matrices and frames (e.g., remove from Connection, DAG, CacheableData, etc). We can map it to BinaryBlockFrame input/output formats whenever required during runtime.

2) Checkpoint: Meanwhile we support spark checkpoints over frames too. Hence, there is no need to disable this rewrite for frames any longer.

3) Frame object: Why is there a need to have 'num rows per block' in the frame object - we could simply use a global optimizer constant whenever needed because this does not describe the actual data.

4) Frame block: Furthermore, why is there a need for leftindexing changes on frame block. The additional indexing operations for multiple output blocks are ok, but the rest should stay in tact, right? Also, please remove any reference to longwritable from frame block (to be replaced with long). Similarly, why do we need a merge over unaligned blocks - any operation that wants to merge blocks should align them first.

5) Frame read/write rdds: Please stick to the current version of reading/writing frame rdds; I did on purpose not implement guarded collect as the memory check needs further investigation first.

6) Execution context frame primitives: The method getFrameRDDHandleForVariable is redundant, given the existence of getRDDHandleForVariable. Also please reuse the existing toFrameBlock (note that there is no notion of bclen for frames).

7) Generalization broadcast matrix object: Could we remove the new matrix broadcast object and frame broadcast object? The valid check should be possible in a generic manner too, right? Also, please double check if we could generalize the partitioned matrix and frame blocks.

8) RDDAggregateUtils: Please revert the signature change of mergeByFrameKey and change the usage in RDDConverterUtils. If there is a key type mismatch, let's call LongWritableToLong before merge.

9) Write meta data file: Please consolidate this new method with the existing metadata write (which is already used for frames too) to avoid code duplication.

10) UtilFunctions: It would be good to move the compare functionality with tolerance out of util functions and into test utils to clearly separate between performance relevant code and tests. Of course, you could still reuse whenever existing functionality directly matches the needs of your tests.

11) Code style: Please update the exception messages of refactored code (e.g., indexing instructions), delete commented code, remove TODOs for MR (as we did not even start this yet), merge multiple static initializers, and make static constants final.
LGTM. Thank you @MechCoder

Can you also remove spark context as a constructor parameter for LogisticRegression class:
`class LogisticRegression(override val uid: String, val sc: SparkContext)`

So it becomes compatible with Spark version. It needs only to convert dataframe to binary bloc matrix, and could be get from dataframe: `dataset.getSqlContext.getSparkContext`

First of all thank you very much for your detailed comments and sorry for my late reply, but we wanted to clarify some things before answering.

To your comments:
1. We are working on a fix for the akka framesize. The problem here seems to be the collect(), which uses akka to retrieve the data. For large data, this should be done via the data transport instead.
2. As we see it, the performance problems are due to 2 drawback of the current Flink version:

a) Flink currently broadcasts data by sending the data to each slot of the task managers separately instead of sharing it among the slots of a task manager. Therefore, the amount of data sent over the network is increased with increasing number of slots per task managers. This seems like a bug, and we hope to fix this relatively fast.

b) As Flink does not support caching of data in the moment, we have to re-read from HDFS every time data sources are accessed.
1. We will try this, as it would at least omit the problem stated in 2 a. Thank you for pointing that out.
2. Good point, we fixed that.
3. Yes, we think this is possible and implement that.

We try to solve the problems mentioned in 1 and 2, but especially 2b. will take some time and needs to be accepted by the Flink community. What do you think is the best way to go in the meanwhile with regards to the integration in SystemML?

Thanks @petro-rudenko  ... that's a good point. It simplifies the interface.

@Wenpei do you mind adding this to the PR ?
Can an Admin verify this patch?

thanks @tgamal - this already looks pretty good. I would just recommend a couple of cleanups: 

1) Rewrite: Could you please apply the rewrite only if the number of parents of (lambda*X) is 1 i.e., the sum is the only consumer? This would ensure it is always beneficial to apply the rewrite.

2) Rewrite code style: First, please remove the unnecessary casts to BinaryOp for data type checks and input references. Second, could we rename the rewrite to 'pushdownSumBinaryMult' and position it after pushdownUnaryAggTransposeOperation to group these similar rewrites together?

3) Test scripts: It would be good to change the testscripts to something like "lambda=sum(X)" to test the rewrite with variables not just literals; furthermore, this would also test an interesting case of common subexpression elimination after rewrites (i.e., sum(X) should be executed just once). In addition, the R script should get only 'expectedDir' as an argument, which would allow you to change the scripts from args[2] to args[1] too.

4) Test scripts copyright: Currently, both R scripts are missing the ASF copyright header - please add this.

Thanks for sharing these thoughts - that sounds good to me. In general, I'd say that, even without caching, the Flink integration would still be a valuable (experimental) feature, because it enables the SystemML community to play around with it and explore advanced features like iteration constructs. So, if we manage to bring the performance to a level that is consistently better than the MR backend (because there is no reason why it should not), I'll endorse it. If later Flink also adds support for distributed caching, even better.

Regarding the broadcast issue, I was actually thinking that the lookup map of matrix blocks might implicitly replicate blocks, if (and only if) broadcasts are internally shared in serialized form. In that case, we could have addressed it with a lazy broadcast partition read (as we do in the MR backend, because a single task seldom reads all broadcast blocks). However, if broadcast are indeed sent to each slot, it is probably a good idea to fix this for the general case.  

So let's have a look into the mmchain instruction and re-evaluate these scenarios once we have it. This should help us understand these characteristics in detail but it will also be useful in general because this operation is the core of major algorithms like LinregCG, GLM, Logreg, and HITS.

Deron, that is a whooping 30% reduction in size. awesome!
Btw, I am curious about the performance impact  -- especially, the code change in `DummyCodeAgent.java`? Also .. since we are removing this dependency with our own implementations, it would be nice to have those sorting and other utilities in a package/library for reusability.
Thanks Matthias for the feedback. I applied and committed the suggested changes

@deroneriksson could you please wrap this perftest into a method and call it 100 times (+ output garbage collection times) to ensure we're comparing the runtime after JIT and without side effects. Also, varying the collection size would be very useful. Thanks.

Addressed all except following comments.
1. Merge alignment: This has not been done for Map case, where slices are created for LHS block from multiple RHS broadcast blocks and merged together. If I shift these slices then LeftIndexing operation to be changed. If performance is an issue for merging slices from broadcast object then I can look into it.
2. Generalization: I will investigate if generalization of Broadcast/Partitioned objects/block can be easily done.
Addressed Generalization comment (number 7).

great job for an initial drop. Minor comments:
- the dependency on "mavenized-jcude-mvn-repo" is fragile, and only a snapshot. What is the release strategy for jcuda, and have proper maven coordinates?
- update the help in DMLScript.java to output proper flags
- for later, it would be good to see one example instruction with a cuda xt call.

thanks @Arvind - please also rebase when you address the following comments:

1) Revert unnecessary syntactic file changes (e.g., RewriteInjectSparkPReadCheckpointing, DAG)

2) Remove any reference to FrameObject from its base class CacheableData to keep it clean and independent of its implementations.

3) Replace the introduced setFrameRDDHandle with setRDDHandle as both work on JavaPairRDD<?,?>

4) There are a couple of formatting issue, e.g., tabs vs spaces (see for example, toFrameBlock)

5) Please, don't use binaryblockframe output info but binaryblock to keep it consistent - only if access to key/value classes is required you should temorarily remap this.

6) SparkUtils: please remove the LongWritable functions as they are unnecessary given that our binary block representation is <Long,FrameBlock>

7) Why did you rename PartitionedBroadcastMatrix - please at least make it PartitionedBroadcast<T extends CacheBlock> to ensure typesafe usage without casts all over the place.

8) Remove def buffer size from frame block as this method only return the value of the constant

9) Please remove the convoluted object type handling from frame block and move it into util functions to be used if necessary from outside.

10) Simplify frame block merge to equal blocksizes

11) Simplify perform slice to row blocks (there should be no need to block for row and column blocks given that a frame block contains all rows)

12) Simplify getSchemaType to valueOf instead of string comparisons.
Perhaps it is a good idea to keep the current knn.dml script in the staging folder. Once the builtin function for the naive knn is supported we can put it under the algorithms folder.

@fmakari Thanks for review, I will ask Feng to address those comments.
Regarding to buildin function to support naive KNN,  can you give us more information?

thanks @tgamal - this is a great feature as the addressed pattern is indeed very common. Couple of comments: 

1) Simplify sparsity estimate to min(sp1+sp2, 1)

2) Please rename the rewrite to 'fuse binary operation chain'. Also use something like 'tmp' as the name for the new ternary operator, and add the linenumbers to the debug output.

3) Fix the lop comments of matrix/scalar operands (exchange the position scalar and second matrix)

4) Make the ValueFunctionWithConstant class member private

5) Test: Rename the test to RewriteFuseBinaryOpChainTest, incl the used dml/R scripts. Further, please decomment the actual testcases, add this class to the testsuite org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.misc.ZPackageSuite, remove all sysout prints from the test class, and remove the class comment copied from a different test. 

6) Why did you have to change RewriteSimplifyRowColSumMVMultTest.java?

7) Add the missing copyright in RewriteAxpy.R and RewriteAxmy.R
